hints.content: Start by understanding the game mechanics. The first two elements of the array are compared, and the larger one stays at the front while the smaller one moves to the end of the array. This process continues until one of the integers wins 'k' consecutive rounds.
Consider how you will keep track of the current winner and their win count. You can use a variable to store the current winner and another variable to count their consecutive wins.
Think about how to implement the logic for moving the smaller integer to the end of the array. You will need to modify the array in each round, so consider using array operations effectively.
Remember that the array contains distinct integers. This means there will never be a tie in any round, simplifying the comparison logic.
You should also consider the case when the array length is very small (like 2). How would your logic change if the array only contained two elements?
As you simulate the rounds, keep an eye on the condition for ending the game: when a player wins 'k' consecutive rounds. Make sure your loop or condition checks for this correctly.
Think about edge cases, such as when 'k' is very large compared to the number of elements in the array. What happens if the winner can easily win 'k' rounds?
You can optimize the simulation by noting that if the current winner is the largest element in the array, they will never lose. This can help you skip unnecessary rounds.
As you implement your solution, ensure you are updating the array correctly after each round. Pay attention to the order of operations when moving elements.
Finally, make sure you return the correct winner after the game ends. The return value should be the integer that won 'k' consecutive rounds, not the index or any other value.

questionNotes: The game ends when an integer wins 'k' consecutive rounds.
Return the integer that wins the game.
